title: Upper and Lower Oddington Walks

images.title: Philip Halling / Lower Oddington
images.caption: Cottages in Lower Oddington complete with a passing Aston Martin car.

images.title: Philip Halling / The Fox, Lower Oddington
images.caption: The Fox, Lower Oddington

images.title: Mike Baldwin / Lower Oddington Village Street
images.caption: Looking east along main street from junction with lane leading to St Nicholas Church. It's a historical church of some note being designated as a Grade I listed building. The church was originally a cell of St Peter’s Benedictine abbey in Gloucester. It was ceded in 1157 to the Diocese of York and exchanged with the Crown in 1547. Part of the nave is twelfth-century and part thirteenth-century.

images.caption: The view from Maugersbury

images.title: Philip Halling / Donnington Brewery
images.caption: Donnington Brewery. The brewery was founded in 1865 in the mill by Thomas Arkell and is still run by a descendant.

images.title: Philip Halling / The village of Longborough
images.caption: The village of Longborough

description: These Gloucestershire based villages are located close to Stow on the Wold in the Cotswolds. This circular walk from the village uses some of the local waymarked footpaths to explore the area. You'll uses sections of the Macmillan Way, Monarch's Way, Gloucestershire Way and the Heart of England Way to visit the neighbouring settlements of Maugersbury, Lower Swell, Longborough, Broadwell and Stow on the Wold. The route takes place on fully waymarked trails with a series of picture postcard Cotswolds villages, peaceful woodland sections and some moderate hill climbs on the way. From the high points there are some wonderful views over the surroundings Cotswolds countryside. You'll also pass the Donnington Brewery near Upper Swell. The walk is coincident with the Donnington Way a Cotswolds pub walk which visits the 15 pubs of the Donnington Brewery. The start point for the walk is Stow on the Wold.

details.subtitle: Pubs/Cafes
details.content: The Horse and Groom in Upper Oddington is set in a delightful Cotswolds stone building dating back to the 16th century. They do fine food and have a lovely large garden to relax in on warmer days. You can find them at postcode GL56 0XH. The pub is also dog friendly. Also of interest is the nearby Amphitheatre at Berrybank. Outdoor summer events here include theatre, music, comedy, and cabaret.
